title: FOUR (Full Outline of UnResponsiveness) Score
description: Grades severity of coma; may be more accurate than Glasgow Coma Scale. Evaluates consciousness level through four components: eye response, motor response, brainstem reflexes, and respiration pattern.

parameters.name: motor_response
parameters.description: Motor response of upper extremities (0-4 points)

result.name: four_score_total
result.description: Total FOUR Score (sum of all four components, range 0-16)

ranges.interpretation: Very severe coma with profound impairment of consciousness. Extensive brainstem dysfunction. Poor prognosis with high mortality risk. Requires intensive neurological monitoring and management.
Severe coma with significant neurological impairment. Substantial brainstem dysfunction present. Guarded prognosis requiring intensive care and frequent neurological assessment.
Moderate coma with variable neurological function. Some brainstem reflexes may be preserved. Prognosis depends on underlying etiology and response to treatment.

ranges.description: Mild to minimal impairment of consciousness
ranges.interpretation: Mild impairment of consciousness with relatively preserved neurological function. Better prognosis with potential for recovery. Continue supportive care and monitor for improvement.

references: Wijdicks EF, Bamlet WR, Maramattom BV, Manno EM, McClelland RL. Validation of a new coma scale: The FOUR score. Ann Neurol. 2005;58(4):585-93.
Wolf CA, Wijdicks EF, Bamlet WR, McClelland RL. Further validation of the FOUR score coma scale by intensive care unit nurses. Mayo Clin Proc. 2007;82(4):435-8.
Stead LG, Wijdicks EF, Bhagra A, et al. Validation of a new coma scale, the FOUR score, in the emergency department. Neurocrit Care. 2009;10(1):50-4.

Kramer AA, Wijdicks EF, Snavely VL, et al. A multicenter prospective study of interobserver agreement using the Full Outline of UnResponsiveness score coma scale in the intensive care unit. Crit Care Med. 2012;40(9):2671-6.
formula: Sum of four components: Eye Response (0-4) + Motor Response (0-4) + Brainstem Reflexes (0-4) + Respiration Pattern (0-4). Total score ranges from 0-16 points.
notes: Developed by Dr. Eelco F.M. Wijdicks to address limitations of the Glasgow Coma Scale
More accurate than GCS, particularly for patients with lowest GCS scores
Each component scored from 0-4 points, with higher scores indicating better function
Eye response assesses eyelid opening and tracking ability
Motor response evaluates upper extremity motor function and command following
Brainstem reflexes include pupillary, corneal, and cough reflexes
Respiration pattern considers breathing patterns and ventilator dependence
Lower total scores indicate more severe coma and worse prognosis
Each point increase is associated with decreased mortality and morbidity
Particularly useful for identifying impending neurological decline
Can be used by nurses and physicians with high inter-rater reliability
Validated in emergency department, ICU, and neurological care settings
